translated: Jātaka
The Nine-Part Collection🔽The Vulture’s Chapter
The Great Suva Jātaka
“When a tree is laden with fruit,

original: Bhuñjanti naṁ vihaṅgamā sampatantā;🔽Khīṇanti ñatvāna dumaṁ phalaccaye,
analyzed: bhuñjanti nam vihaṅgamā sampatantā  dumam phalaccaye
translated: Birds flock to it and eat;🔽Knowing the tree is exhausted of fruit,

original: Disodisaṁ yanti tato vihaṅgamā.🔽Cara cārikaṁ lohitatuṇḍa māmari,
analyzed: disodisam yanti tatas vihaṅgamā  cara cārikam lohita tuṇḍa māmari
translated: The birds fly away in all directions.🔽Wander, Suva, with your red beak, don’t be lazy.
Why do you burn up on a dry tree, Suva?
Tell me, Suva, as if you were speaking to a friend,
Why don’t you leave the dry tree?”
“Those who are friends to their friends,
In happiness and in suffering, swan,

analyzed: khīṇam a khīṇam api na tam jahanti
translated: Don’t abandon them when they’re exhausted or not exhausted.
The good remember the good, swan.

analyzed: sā uham satam aññatarā asmi hasa
translated: I am one of those good, swan,

original: Ñātī ca me hoti sakhā ca rukkho;
analyzed: ñātī ca me hoti sakhā ca rukkhaḥ
translated: And the tree is my relative and friend.
For the sake of life, I can’t abandon it.

analyzed: khīṇanti ñatvāna na ha isa dhammo
translated: Knowing it’s exhausted, that’s not the good way.”
“It’s good when friendship is made,
When there’s friendship and affection.
If you approve of this good way,
You’re praiseworthy to the discerning.
I will give you a boon,
O bird who has attained his desire;
Choose a boon, O Vakkaṅga,
whatever you desire in your mind.”

analyzed: varam ca me hasa bhavam dadeyya
translated: “If you, Sir, would give me a boon,
and this tree would regain its life,
with branches and leaves fully grown,
may it stand shining as a honey tree.”
“See that excellent tree with its fruit,
may it be with you together with the udumbara;
with branches and leaves fully grown,
may it stand shining as a honey tree.”
“Thus may you be happy, my friend,
together with all your relatives;
just as I am happy today,
having seen the fruitful tree.”
“Having given the boon to Suvās,
and having made the tree fruitful,
he departed together with his wife
to the Nandana Grove of the gods.”
The Mahāsuva Jātaka is the third.
